description: Two god-like monarchs rule two labyrinthine prisons for the living and the dead beneath the earth, and humanity throw their dissidents and criminals down into the darkness for eternity. But the Red King wants out, to reshape the world above as he has the world below. In The Red Labyrinth, Ben Peek uses the short, sharp storytelling required for great novella writing to deliver a story of population control, service without hope, fear of punishment, of falling into line with the horrible status quo, of hopelessness and of rebellion. Zoja has learned to read and reproduce books of history she smuggles into her home–a highly illegal act in a society of controlled knowledge. She is careful and wary, looking for knowledge and history and not profit. But she is not careful enough, and finds herself thrown into the darkness and beneath the Red King’s eye. title: REVIEW: The Red Labyrinth by Ben Peek
